name: Transcranial Focused Ultrasound (tFUS)
summary: A non-invasive neuromodulation and lesioning technique using focused ultrasound waves to either modulate brain activity or ablate targeted tissue for conditions such as tremor and depression.
description: Transcranial Focused Ultrasound (tFUS) is an emerging neuromodulation and neurosurgical technology that uses highly focused ultrasound beams delivered through the skull to specific brain regions. Depending on the intensity, tFUS can either transiently modulate neuronal activity or permanently ablate tissue. It is FDA-approved for essential tremor and Parkinson’s disease tremor, with ongoing research into psychiatric conditions such as depression and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Because it is incisionless, tFUS avoids many risks of open neurosurgery, but requires MRI guidance and specialized equipment.

metadata.treatment_duration: Single session for ablation; multiple for neuromodulation protocols

contraindications: Skull density ratio too low for effective targeting
MRI contraindications (e.g., metallic implants, severe claustrophobia)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe but can cause headache, dizziness, balance problems, or transient neurological deficits. Ablation procedures may carry risk of permanent deficits.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: High for essential tremor; early/moderate for psychiatric disorders.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Dozens of trials in tremor disorders; increasing number of pilot studies in psychiatry.

sections.text: Focused ultrasound delivers acoustic energy through the skull to precise brain regions. Low-intensity tFUS can alter neuronal excitability and brain network activity without tissue damage, while high-intensity focused ultrasound (HIFU) induces thermal ablation for permanent lesioning. MRI is used to guide and monitor energy delivery.

sections.preparation: Patient undergoes MRI and skull density assessment. Head is immobilized in stereotactic frame.
procedure: MRI-guided targeting of brain region (e.g., thalamus for tremor).
Application of low- or high-intensity ultrasound pulses.
Temperature monitored in real time via MR thermography.
sections.frequency: Single ablation session for tremor; repeated sessions possible for neuromodulation research.

short_term: Marked functional improvement in motor symptoms
long_term: Sustained tremor suppression; potential psychiatric symptom improvement with ongoing research

rare: Permanent neurological deficits from mis-targeted ablation

ideal_candidates: Patients with disabling essential tremor not controlled by medication
Parkinson’s disease patients with tremor-dominant symptoms
Patients unsuitable or unwilling to undergo invasive surgery

facility: Hospitals with MRI-guided focused ultrasound equipment

studies: Large RCTs demonstrate sustained tremor reduction with thalamic ablation.
Pilot studies suggest modulation of mood and cognitive symptoms.
Evidence for depression and OCD is preliminary.
sections.limitations: Expensive, limited availability, skull density variability reduces applicability.

sections.total_treatment_cost: One-time cost for ablation; experimental neuromodulation protocols vary.
sections.insurance_coverage: Increasingly covered for essential tremor and Parkinson’s tremor.
sections.cost_effectiveness: High upfront cost but durable benefit for tremor disorders.

sections.elderly: Generally safe if medically stable; tremor population often older.
sections.pregnancy: Not studied; avoided due to MRI and ultrasound exposure.
sections.comorbidities: Careful screening in patients with cardiac or neurological disorders.

items: tFUS is unique in combining non-invasiveness with surgical precision.
Two main modes: low-intensity (neuromodulation) and high-intensity (ablation).
